This message can be easily defined to meet your requirements.

The open enrollment process uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the open enrollment process to each employee. For example, full-time employees may enroll in different plans than part-time employees, or the enrollment process for corporate employees may be different from regional employees.

This plan provides spouse coverage, and there is no record of your spouse. You may either select a different plan, or quit the enrollment process and try again after you have added your spouse using the dependent task.

This plan provides spouse coverage, and there is no record of your spouse's birthdate. You may either select a different plan, or quit the enrollment process and try again after you have added your spouse's birthdate using the dependent task.

This plan provides spouse coverage, and there is more than one spouse on file for you. You may either select a different plan, or quit the enrollment process and try again after you have updated your spouse's information using the dependent task.

This plan is based on your age, which is not in the system. You may either select a different plan, or quit the enrollment process and try again after you give your birthdate to the benefits department

This message for new hires can be easily defined to meet your requirements.

The new hire enrollment process uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the open enrollment process to each employee. For example, full-time employees may enroll in different plans than part-time employees, or the enrollment process for corporate employees may be different from regional employees.

During the enrollment process, all of the information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.
Life event has not been processed. Contact the benefits department.
You are not eligible to enroll for any benefits. Contact the benefits department.
You are not eligible to enroll for any benefits. Contact the benefits department. You have eligible plans which may not be elected.
You cannot use web enrollment. Contact the benefits department. You already have benefit elections that begin on or after the date of your life event.
Your benefits have not been fully updated. Contact the benefits department.

This message for the Birth Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if they have a baby. The Birth Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the birth life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. For example, for the birth event you may allow employees to add additional life insurance, or change the level of coverage within a health plan, while a divorce event may not allow employees to add additional coverage. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

This message for the Adoption Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if they adopt a child. The Adoption Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the adoption life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. For example, for the adoption event you may allow employees to add additional life insurance, or change the level of coverage within a health plan while a divorce event may not allow employees to add additional coverage. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

This message for the Divorce Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if they get divorced. The Divorce Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the divorce life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. For example, a divorce event may not allow employees to increase life insurance coverage while the birth event you may allow employees to increase life insurance coverage, or employees to add additional life insurance, or change the level of coverage within a health plan, while a divorce event may not allow employees to add additional coverage. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

This message for the Legal Separation Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if they legally separate. The Legal Separation Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the legal separation life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. For example a legal separation event may not allow employees to increase life insurance coverage while the birth event you may allow employees to increase life insurance coverage, or employees to add additional life insurance, or change the level of coverage within a health plan, while a divorce event may not allow employees to add additional coverage. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

This message for the Marriage Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if they get married. The Marriage Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the Marriage life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. For example, a marriage event may not allow employees to increase life insurance coverage while the birth event you may allow employees to increase life insurance coverage, or employees to add additional life insurance, or change the level of coverage within a health plan, while a divorce event may not allow employees to add additional coverage. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

This message for the Spouse Employment Life Event can be easily tailored to describe the changes employees at your company may make to benefits if their spouse changes employment. The Spouse Employment Event uses the flexibility of the benefits system to tailor the Spouse Employment life event benefit changes to each employee. You can define the benefits that the employee can change for this event. information the employee needs to make a decision regarding his or her benefits will be presented. This includes access to user defined plan descriptions, which can be a simple outline of the critical plan information or could be the entire Summary Plan Description.

If you choose to keep these benefits and you want to make additional changes later, you will have to contact the benefits department. If you are not sure of the elections you made, select cancel and then choose exit and make elections later. You can then use the web enrollment process when you have made your final decisions. Choose 'OK' to keep these benefits.

There was a server error when trying to add a benefit in BN31.1. The system created pending benefit records in BS31 for all benefits that were not added. Review the records in BS31 to determine how to update the employee's benefits

There was a server error when trying to add a dependent benefit in HR13.3. The system created pending benefits in BS30 for all dependent benefits which were not added. Review the records in BS30 to determine how to update the employee's benefits
There was a server error when trying to add a dependent benefit in BS30. Delete any pending dependent benefits in BS30, and have the employee enroll again.
Review the records in BS31 to determine how to update the employee's benefits

There was a server error when trying to stop a benefit in BS32. The system created pending benefit records in BS31 for all benefits that were not updated. This may include stops and adds. Review the records in BS31 to determine how to update the employee's benefits
There was a server error when deleting a pending benefit in BS31. Delete all records for the employee in BS31, and have the employee enroll again.
There was a server error when deleting a pending benefit in BS31. Delete any pending benefits in BS31, and have the employee enroll again.
There was a server error when deleting a benefit in BS32. Delete all records for the employee in BS31, and have the employee enroll again.
Review the records in BS31 and/or BS30 to determine how to update the employee's benefits

For a given benefit, all beneficiaries must have the same distribution type: percent or amount. To change the distribution type, you must delete and re-enter the beneficiar(ies) with the new distribution type.
For a given benefit, all beneficiaries must have the same distribution type. Please select 'Percent'.
For a given benefit, all beneficiaries must have the same distribution type. Please select 'Amount'.

A beneficiary is a person, estate, trust or organization that you designate to receive monetary benefits if you die while covered under a benefit plan. You may have one or many beneficiaries. Beneficiaries may be primary or contingent.
What is the difference between a primary and a contingent beneficiary?

A primary beneficiary receives some monetary benefit if you die while covered under a benefit plan. A contingent beneficiary receives benefits only if your primary beneficiary is deceased or cannot be found.
How do my benefits get divided among many beneficiaries?
You can designate the distribution of your benefits among your beneficiaries either by specifying a percentage or by specifying a specific dollar amount for each beneficiary.

If you have more than one beneficiary for a plan, all designations for that plan must be made in the same manner (that is, all percentages or dollar amounts). If you use percentages, the total cannot exceed 100%.
